sourceMeaningMnemonic: A <radical>guard</radical> is at your door and wants some of your <radical>grain</radical>s. This is the <kanji>tax</kanji> you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grains were used like currency, so it makes sense that there was a grain tax in the olden days.
meaningInfo: Can you imagine a guard coming to your door and demanding you pay your grain tax?
readingMnemonic: You have to pay this <kanji>tax</kanji>, because if you don't the guard will cut you down with his special German saber, a <reading>zei</reading>ber (<ja>ぜい</ja>). "Don't you hear vat I zei? Pay ze tax or I vill zlei you!" he shouts.
readingInfo: You don't want to be sliced with the zeiber, so you listen to vat he zei zei zei's and pay the tax.
